resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
github-actions[bot] commented on PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#issuecomment-1151823251

   :warning: Ticket **has not been started in JIRA**, please click 'Start Progress'.

kou commented on PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#issuecomment-1152000203

   Debug build isn't fast...

pitrou commented on PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#issuecomment-1156318806

   Perhaps disable CMAKE_UNITY_BUILD? (perhaps the workers lack RAM)

kou commented on PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#issuecomment-1157183576

   `CMAKE_UNITY_BUILD` was unrelated... (CI jobs still timed out.)
   
   It seems that we need to accept 60+ min build time without cache. We can build them in 15-25 min with cache. Can we increase `timeout-minutes` in `.github/workflows/cpp.yml` to `90` from `60`?

assignUser commented on code in PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#discussion_r899182889


##########
.github/workflows/cpp.yml:
##########
@@ -260,7 +260,7 @@ jobs:
     name: AMD64 Windows MinGW ${{ matrix.mingw-n-bits }} C++
     runs-on: windows-2019
     if: ${{ !contains(github.event.pull_request.title, 'WIP') }}
-    timeout-minutes: 60
+    timeout-minutes: 90

Review Comment:
   Seeing that it also times out with 90: https://github.com/apache/arrow/runs/6912383497?check_suite_focus=true
   Should we bump it up some more? A long build is annoying but a canceled build is just wasted time...

pitrou commented on code in PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#discussion_r899200760


##########
.github/workflows/cpp.yml:
##########
@@ -260,7 +260,7 @@ jobs:
     name: AMD64 Windows MinGW ${{ matrix.mingw-n-bits }} C++
     runs-on: windows-2019
     if: ${{ !contains(github.event.pull_request.title, 'WIP') }}
-    timeout-minutes: 60
+    timeout-minutes: 90

Review Comment:
   If it times out with 90 then something is going really wrong.

kou commented on PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#issuecomment-1159886165

   It seems that the following configurations are the best for now:
   
   * Increase timeout to 90 minutes from 60 minutes to avoid time-out without cache
   * Use release build not debug build
     * Release build is faster than debug build
     
   If there are no objections, I'll merge this in a few days.

wjones127 commented on PR #13359:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13359#issuecomment-1163145039

   Thank you @kou!

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
When ccache is cold, the MinGW builds sometimes exceed the (large) 55 minutes timeout:
https://github.com/apache/arrow/runs/6806190892?check_suite_focus=true

C++ compile times have always been a concern on CI, but it may only grow as the codebase expands.

comments.body:
Hm, the timeout seems to be set pretty tight as even if [ccache hits|https://github.com/apache/arrow/runs/6782212921?check_suite_focus=true#step:7:57] the mingw job needs 40-58 minutes to finish. Other than improving caching I am not sure what we can do (for now) to improve this, as we are locked into the runner hardware with only 2 cores. So I think it would make sense to increase the timeout to prevent jobs from failing because of that.

I do think that the key for the ccache-cache is set to restrictive {{key: cpp-ccache-mingw$\{\{ matrix.mingw-n-bits \}\}-$\{\{ hashFiles('cpp/**')\}\}}} as it will miss on any change in the cpp dir. Maybe my understanding of ccache is wrong but isn't invalidating the cached version of changed source files part of ccache's function?
A less specific key would also mean fewer caches (global cache size is limited per repo) -> fewer evictions -> fewer misses
The key is quite restrictive, but the "restore-keys" isn't. That said, I agree that it may be counter-productive to compute such a discriminative cache key.

To come back to the timeout problem, though, the obvious solution is indeed to bump the timeout.

However, it is quite worrying that pure C++ builds on CI are now nearing the one hour build time. One thing specific to the MinGW builds is the fact that they build in Release mode (probably because Debug builds on Windows are complicated). One mitigation would be to override CFLAGS and CXXFLAGS to disable most optimizations.
I'll try changing build type to Debug from Release.
Have we ever tried linking with lld (LLVM linker) instead? I've heard it's substantially faster than the built-in MinGW linker. In theory it's fully compatible with GCC >= 10.
You can already try to enable ld.gold using {{-DARROW_USE_LD_GOLD=on}}

I added these jobs to confirm our code base can work as a MSYS2's MinGW package.
So I don't want to mix GCC and LLVM linker because MSYS2's MinGW package doesn't mix them.

We can't use ld.gold for this because ld.gold is only for ELF.
